columns.text: **a.** In this problem. we simply need to show the relationship between the cashflow and the sales volume by placing them together in a single formula.

In order to do this, we first need to show the formula for the operating cashflow:

$$\begin{aligned}
OCF&=[(P-v) \times Q - FC]\times (1-T)+(T \times D)
\end{aligned}$$

Where,

$$\begin{aligned}
P&=\text{Price per unit}\\
v&=\text{Variable cost per unit}\\
Q&=\text{Quantity}\\
FC&=\text{Fixed cost}\\
T&=\text{Tax rate}\\
D&=\text{Depreciation}
\end{aligned}$$

**b.** Looking at the Wettway problem that we encountered throughout the chapter, we need to solve for the accounting break-even. This can be solved using the formula above. Substituting the given values, we have:

$$\begin{aligned}
Q&=\dfrac{\frac{(\$3,500,000\div5)-\$700,000\times 0.21}{1-0.21}+\$500,000}{\$40,000-\$20,000}\\
&=\dfrac{\$1,200,000}{\$20,000}\\
&=60
\end{aligned}$$

The accounting break-even is achieved at $60$ units.

For the cash break-even, this can be achieved if the operating cashflow is zero. This can be solved using the formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
Q&=\dfrac{FC}{P-v}
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:
$$\begin{aligned}
Q&=\dfrac{\$500,000}{\$40,000-\$20,000}\\
&=\dfrac{\$500,000}{\$20,000}\\
&=25
\end{aligned}$$

The cash break-even point is at $25$ units

Finally, we can use the formula in Step 2 to solve for the financial break-even point. To get the OCF, we will divide initial investment by the annuity factor for $21\%$ for $5$ years which is $2.926$:

$$\begin{aligned}
Q&=\dfrac{\frac{OCF-(T \times D)}{1-T}+FC}{P-v}
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
Q&=\dfrac{\frac{(\$3,500,000/2.926)-(0.21 \times \$700,000)}{1-0.21}+\$500,000}{\$40,000-\$20,000}\\
&=\dfrac{\$1,328,066.138+\$500,000}{\$20,000}\\
&=91.40
\end{aligned}$$

The financial break-even is at $91.4$ units.
